ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Chord progressions in major and minor keys, rhythm in compound meter with multiple parts, singing both prepared and unseen diatonic pieces
I developed my ear training and sight singing.

I learned lots about roman numeral theory, chord progressions, and cadences in this course. Much of what we did was related to sight reading melodies or rhythms, or hearing short segments of music and being able to determine its progression.

I learned so much about music theory, especially the structure of chord progressions in major and minor. I really improved my sightreading skills (rhythmic and melodic) and trained my ear through our dictation exercises.

I learned a lot about major/minor chord progressions and how they operate. The class focused a lot on improving skills like sight reading and dictation, which was super helpful and not nearly as stressful as you might think.
I got better at detecting the quality of a chord and also detecting intervals.
Some competency with solfege singing, and the ability to transcribe a (simple) piano piece from only a couple of listenings.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Dr. Adam is definitely a strength. He teaches in a very understanding and relatable way, and he meets students where they are for the most part in terms of their musical context before the start of the course. I would say that having only 30 min. section with one other person was a bit strange at times and may not have been as helpful as a bigger section with a bit more time.

weaknesses - not well organized, hard to tell how to improve
strength - interesting content
My only complaint about this class is that some extent of ear training is assumed. This makes the class harder to keep up with if you have none, but Dr. Adam is very understanding and accommodating!
Perhaps finding a way to foster a more collaborative environment (group work, etc).
Wouldn't change a thing!!
The course is super relaxed and still helps you improve at sight reading/dictation from whatever level you started at. Dr. Adam made the class very low pressure. No weaknesses!

Strengths: Practicing everyday, class sessions were very practical and emphasized practicing as a way to get better

Weaknesses: Course goals/objectives/expectations were not clear at the beginning; started very quickly and barely received guidance on how to approach the different exercises

+ This class was originally the "section" of MUSI 210, and Professor Adams tries to keep it true to its dynamic, practice-based roots. He keeps lecturing to a minimum, and includes some sort of sight-singing or rhythmic practices in most every class. This was a very enjoyable 50 minutes each week.
- Professor Adams has a peculiar, almost vindictive attitude towards people with perfect pitch. Under the theory that they should learn to recognize notes "the normal way", by gauging the size of intervals, he made us transcribe dictations in a different key than they were actually played in. This caused quite a few headaches for the fourth of the class with some degree of absolute pitch -- as it forces you to actually fight competing impulses, where one part of your brain says "that's a C#", but the other says "no, he said this piece was in C!" The only solution, as far as I can tell, is to practice suppressing your ear 
for pitch, rather than learning to use it to its fullest potential. I know Dr. Adams just wants to "even the playing field," but the result triggers a sort of psychological warfare which actually disadvantages those with some degree of absolute pitch.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you like music or want to be a better musician and haven't had much music theory before! I feel like my knowledge of chord progressions now has made me a better overall musician
I would definitely recommend this class to anyone looking to improve their aural skills! It creates a foundation for future music composition classes and overall just makes you a better musician.
Great course if you've done some harmonic and rhythmic dictation before
Yes you learn a lot of important skills such as sight singing and rhythmic and harmonic dictation. The class is also fun and engaging.

Yes- I initially thought that if you had perfect pitch, you would be better off not taking this course, but I now realize that there were so many skills and ideas that were honed in on despite the kind of ear you had, which was mainly due to the way professor Adam taught the course. The TA, P. Bixby, was also very helpful.
Yes! I found the knowledge I gained to be very beneficial to my musicianship, as well as interesting in its applications to music I listen to all the time!

I would absolutely 100% recommend this course to another student, as long as they are involved with music in some way. It was so much fun, so helpful for my understanding of music theory and musical ear, and there was almost no homework.
Yes! Id recommend this class to anyone who wants to learn more about chord progressions and improve sight reading/dictation. The class does melody and rhythm exercises.
If you need a coreq for lessons, this is a good option (though perhaps not if you have perfect pitch; see above).

extras.title: MUSI 218 01 - Aural Skills for Tonal Music
